Class EvictingDictionary<TKey, TValue>

Represents a fixed-capacity dictionary that automatically removes entries based on a chosen eviction policy, such as First-In-First-Out (FIFO), Least Recently Used (LRU), or Least Frequently Used (LFU).

Namespace: Bodu.Collections.Generic
Assembly: Bodu.CoreLib.dll
Syntax
[Serializable]
public class EvictingDictionary<TKey, TValue> : IDictionary<TKey, TValue>, ICollection<KeyValuePair<TKey, TValue>>, IEnumerable<KeyValuePair<TKey, TValue>>, IDictionary, ICollection, IEnumerable where TKey : notnull
Type Parameters
Name Description
TKey

Specifies the type of keys in the dictionary.
TValue

Specifies the type of values in the dictionary.
Remarks

EvictingDictionary<TKey, TValue> maintains a maximum number of key-value pairs and automatically evicts items when capacity is exceeded. Eviction is determined by a specified EvictionPolicy, allowing this dictionary to behave like a queue, an access-order cache, or a frequency-based cache.

The supported EvictionPolicy values are:

  • FIFO evicts the item that was added first, in first-in, first-out order.
  • LRU evicts the least recently accessed item, updating the usage order on every read and write.
  • LFU evicts the least frequently accessed item, promoting items as their usage count increases.

Common operations supported by EvictingDictionary<TKey, TValue> include:

  • Add(TKey, TValue) adds a key-value pair and may evict an existing entry if the dictionary is at capacity.
  • TryGetValue(TKey, out TValue) retrieves a value by key and updates its usage metadata if the policy is LRU or LFU.
  • Remove(TKey) removes the entry for a specified key.
  • Clear() removes all entries from the dictionary.

Unlike Dictionary<TKey, TValue>, this type ensures the total number of entries never exceeds the configured Capacity. The eviction behavior makes it useful for caching scenarios, memory-bound lookup tables, or history-aware key-value stores.

EvictingDictionary<TKey, TValue> allows null keys and values (for reference types) and supports custom key equality via IEqualityComparer<T>.

The following examples demonstrate typical usage scenarios for EvictingDictionary<TKey, TValue>. 

using System;
using Bodu.CoreLib.Collections.Generic;

// Example 1: Basic FIFO cache
var cache = new EvictingDictionary<string, int>(capacity: 3, policy: EvictionPolicy.FIFO);
cache.Add("one", 1);
cache.Add("two", 2);
cache.Add("three", 3);
cache.Add("four", 4); // "one" is evicted (FIFO)

Console.WriteLine(cache.ContainsKey("one"));   // False
Console.WriteLine(cache.ContainsKey("four"));  // True
 
// Example 2: Least Recently Used (LRU) behavior
var lruCache = new EvictingDictionary<string, string>(3, EvictionPolicy.LRU);
lruCache.Add("A", "Apple");
lruCache.Add("B", "Banana");
lruCache.Add("C", "Carrot");

var _ = lruCache["A"]; // Access "A" to make it most recently used
lruCache.Add("D", "Date"); // Evicts "B" (least recently used)

Console.WriteLine(lruCache.ContainsKey("B")); // False
Console.WriteLine(lruCache.ContainsKey("A")); // True
 
// Example 3: Least Frequently Used (LFU) behavior
var lfuCache = new EvictingDictionary<int, string>(2, EvictionPolicy.LFU);
lfuCache.Add(1, "one");
lfuCache.Add(2, "two");

// Access 1 multiple times
var temp = lfuCache[1];
temp = lfuCache[1];

// Add a third item, triggering LFU eviction
lfuCache.Add(3, "three"); // Evicts 2 (less frequently accessed than 1)

Console.WriteLine(lfuCache.ContainsKey(2)); // False
Console.WriteLine(lfuCache.ContainsKey(1)); // True
 
// Example 4: Using custom equality comparer
var ignoreCaseDict = new EvictingDictionary<string, string>(
    capacity: 2,
    policy: EvictionPolicy.LRU,
    comparer: StringComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase
);

ignoreCaseDict["Key"] = "Value";
Console.WriteLine(ignoreCaseDict.ContainsKey("key")); // True

Constructors

EvictingDictionary()

Initializes a new empty EvictingDictionary<TKey, TValue> with the default capacity and eviction policy.

Declaration
public EvictingDictionary()
Remarks

The default capacity is 16, and the default eviction policy is LRU.

EvictingDictionary(IDictionary<TKey, TValue>)

Initializes a new EvictingDictionary<TKey, TValue> by copying entries from the specified dictionary, using default capacity and eviction policy.

Declaration
public EvictingDictionary(IDictionary<TKey, TValue> source)
Parameters
Type Name Description
IDictionary<TKey, TValue> source

The dictionary from which key-value pairs are copied. Must not be null.
Remarks

If the number of entries in source exceeds the default capacity (16), only the most recent entries are retained according to the default eviction policy (LRU).

Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentNullException

Thrown when source is null.

OrderedKeys

Returns the keys in logical eviction order according to the current policy: FIFO and LRU are in insertion/access order; LFU is in increasing frequency order.

Clear()

Removes all entries from the dictionary.

Declaration
public void Clear()
Remarks

This operation also resets any internal state related to eviction tracking, such as usage frequency (LFU) or access order (LRU).

TryGetValue(TKey, out TValue)

Attempts to retrieve the value associated with the specified key.

Declaration
public bool TryGetValue(TKey key, out TValue value)
Parameters
Type Name Description
TKey key

The key of the value to retrieve.
TValue value

When this method returns, contains the value associated with the specified key, if the key is found; otherwise, the default value for the type of the value parameter.

Returns
Type Description
bool

true if the dictionary contains an element with the specified key; otherwise, false.
Remarks

If the eviction policy is LRU or LFU, accessing a key through this method will update its usage metadata.

Events

ItemEvicted

Occurs immediately after an item is evicted from the EvictingDictionary<TKey, TValue> due to capacity limits.

Declaration
public event Action<TKey, TValue>? ItemEvicted
Event Type
Type Description
Action<TKey, TValue>
Remarks

This event is raised after the item has been removed from the collection, based on the configured EvictionPolicy (e.g., FIFO, LRU, or LFU).

Consumers can use this event to record historical data, notify observers, or synchronize external caches. The key and value provided are no longer present in the dictionary.

Examples
var cache = new EvictingDictionary<string, int>(capacity: 2, policy: EvictionPolicy.FIFO);
cache.ItemEvicted += (key, value) =>
{
    Console.WriteLine($""[AfterEvict] {key} = {value}"");
};

cache.Add(""A"", 1);
cache.Add(""B"", 2);
cache.Add(""C"", 3); // Triggers ItemEvicted for ""A""

ItemEvicting

Occurs immediately before an item is evicted from the EvictingDictionary<TKey, TValue> due to capacity limits.

Declaration
public event Action<TKey, TValue>? ItemEvicting
Event Type
Type Description
Action<TKey, TValue>
Remarks

This event is raised before the item is removed from the collection, allowing consumers to inspect the key and value before eviction occurs.

Common use cases include diagnostics, logging, cache warm-up, or state mirroring. This event is informational and cannot cancel or delay eviction.

Examples
var cache = new EvictingDictionary<string, int>(capacity: 2, policy: EvictionPolicy.FIFO);
cache.ItemEvicting += (key, value) =>
{
    Console.WriteLine($""[BeforeEvict] {key} = {value}"");
};

cache.Add(""A"", 1);
cache.Add(""B"", 2);
cache.Add(""C"", 3); // Triggers ItemEvicting for ""A""
